description:
《英文天天写》是沪江社团一档写作类社刊，其目的在于提升大家的英语写作能力。每期节目主持人都会给出一个话题，积极参加的童鞋还会得到主持人的专业点评哦！想提高英语写作的童鞋千万不要错过哦！去沪江社团订阅本社刊！

       

话题：

Writing: imagine a scenario or express your opinion
Particular
Particular means a specific one. What does the particular one refer to? Why does it stand out from the rest?
This week's topic: They were looking for a particular one... (90-110 words)

Suggestions:
1) a particular person in a crowd
2) a particular folder in a stack of documents
3) meet at a particular time
4) looking for a particular design
5) Instead of writing a scenario, feel free to comment on the story below.

范例1：

Another reason for him being so early on this particular day was that he wanted to get started on another new project. The several projects on hand were finishing up; there were only a few loose ends here and there to be tied up. That should not take long, and that was what this early morning meeting was about: making sure all the minor details were taken cared of. Of course, it was common practice that new projects were assigned without the older ones being completely closed; Shawn's team had been assigned a new project.

想要得到专业主持人的点评和意见吗？快来节目现场一试身手吧>>

  • 图：60年过去了这场婚礼依然是全球最梦幻的

title: 英文天天写：Particular

description:
Tricky to explain, but kind of important - a decent way perhaps to describe negative interest rates. Only a few months ago, central banks across Europe started charging negative rates on certain types of bank account. Now though the same is happening for government bonds - the money that governments hand out to investors in return for them buying a slice of a government's debt. Swiss ten-year bonds went negative for the first time last week. Germany is expected to follow soon. Even debt-threatened Spain is now negative for six-month bonds. It's all been accelerated by the European Central Bank which launched its trillion-euro bond-buying scheme last month. So what is going on and what are the risks? I asked Richard Seagle, income strategist at the global investment banking firm Jefferies International, and Katie Martin, European markets editor at the Wall Street Journal.

What we've seen in the past couple of weeks is that this is reaching new levels. Bonds with longer- and longer-term maturities are falling into this camp. Even Spanish short-term debt was issued last week with negative yields. So it's big, it's snowballing and the question really is only how far can this go? How many countries can be sucked into this group? Fighting it is a bit of a fool's errand because you have to believe that the European Central Bank is not going to do what it's already doing, what it promised to do, which is buying loads and loads of bonds in an effort to support the Eurozone economy. 

声明：音视频均来自互联网链接，仅供学习使用。本网站自身不存储、控制、修改被链接的内容。“沪江英语”高度重视知识产权保护。当如发现本网站发布的信息包含有侵犯其著作权的链接内容时，请联系我们，我们将依法采取措施移除相关内容或屏蔽相关链接。>>零基础直达流利生活口语班<<
